awd_titl_txt: TWC: Small: Designing Strong End-to-End Authentication Mechanisms for Modern Telephony Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Telephony is the dominant means of digital communication across the globe. With more than six billion users worldwide, these systems represent the only communications infrastructure available to the majority of people on the planet. Authentication has traditionally been the most central security issue for telephony providers. Tied directly to the billing process, authentication ensures that providers are able to correctly charge specific parties for their network usage. The problem with these techniques is that they do very little for end users -- while the network is fairly certain of the identity of the user and the user of the network, these techniques do nothing to assist the user in determining the identity of the party on the other end of a call. As primary evidence of this problem, well over US$2 Billion is lost every year via phone fraud. These attacks are possible because the model of authentication addresses only the provider's needs, not those of their customers. If attacks such as Caller ID spoofing are ever to be mitigated, the diverse landscape of telephony systems will require stronger, more universally applicable mechanisms. 

This research addresses authentication problems by tying modern telephony systems into the global authentication infrastructure that has dramatically improved transaction security over the Web during the past two decades.   This proposal seeks to create transformative techniques to mitigate much of modern phone fraud (e.g., IRS fraud, bank/wire fraud).
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Spam phone calls, whether in the form of automated robocalls or targeted manipulation attempts, have seen a substantial rise over the last decade. This work is the first to look at developing multiple strong mechanisms for detecting such calls, with a particular focus on building robust authentication mechanisms for identifying the participating parties. We specifically aimed to develop verifiable Caller-ID mechanisms, and then develop the necessary infrastructure to support their use. This grant then allowed us to look at how these mechanisms would be perceived by users, allowing us both to analyze the current state of the art in robocall alert applications but also to create appealing user interfaces for when end-to-end authentication protocols (e.g., ours, STIR/SHAKEN) are eventually deployed. The lessons learned in this work are invaluable and wide ranging, and have already transcended this work into deployment-focused follow-on projects.

This work has resulted in 10+ conference and journal papers (most of which were published at the top venues in their respective fields), 4 patent disclosures (Issued: 15/941,311; Allowed: 16/357,998, Filed: 17/446,023; Pending: 16/304,412), partially funded 3 Ph.D. students (all three of whom initially took tenure track faculty positions at Carnegie R1 institutions after graduation) and created research opportunities for 10+ MS and BS students (many of whom come from underrepresented groups). 


Last Modified: 01/26/2022
Modified by: Patrick Traynor
